script: Wave to your father.
Today, I will be delivered to the Archduke Ferdinand at the gala.
I expect you to behave with distinction on this hunt.
and Godspeed.
Could they not fit you a rocking chair on that horse, grandad?
You'll all be my gun bearers by evening. Have no doubt of that!
Ha!
Major, there's no path there!
Good boy.
To death... the best source to life!
-Daddy did it! -Come here, you.
-Daddy! -Well done, Daddy.
Someday, you and I will go hunting together.
We're going to be late.
Oh, God, it's this damn thing.
You must be so pleased with yourselves. You, men.
Making us wear these awful things.
I know.
Well?
Rather lovely.
What is it? What's amiss?
Well, my darling, I will be the only man there tonight, of my rank, -whose uniform is unadorned. -How can that matter now?
The great Secretary Bryce will be at the gala.
Oh, Ms. Fawcett...
You've no medals.
Oh, no, Mr. Bryce. You see, I've been terribly busy teaching ancient militiamen to point their rifles at tree stumps, so...
No, no.
No medals for me, Sir.
Tell me...
Who's this Secretary Bryce when he's at home?
The last man here upon whom we might possibly rely for advancement.
I see.
I'm getting older, cheeky... and very impatient of lost years.
I know the medals are ridiculous. I do.
Honor's mine, Sir.
Good to meet you. Meet Secretary Bryce, Secretary Bryce, Mrs. Bellamy.
May I present this magnificent animal.
Well, I am dancing with you, so I've got the better of the bargain.
Spoken too soon.
By the way, who got the kill?
Oh, that would be Major Fawcett, Mr. Secretary.
Well, we should invite him to supper.
Oh...
Well, may I say... he's been rather unfortunate in his choice of ancestors.
I see.
Well, then...
Tell me. How is Lady Bernard?
-Sir? -You're off to London tomorrow, to the Royal Geographical Society.
The Royal Geographical, Society?
Thank you, Sir.
Thank you.
Major Fawcett, Sir.
Oh, yes, yes. Come in.
I am Sir George Goldie. President of the RGS.
This is Mr. John Scott Keltie, our Secretary.
-How do you do, Major? -How do you do, Sir?
Our paths have not crossed during our work here several years back, did they?
They did not, Sir.
I was likely consumed with my studies at the time.
Of course.
Yes, I've served in Ceylon, and in Hong Kong before that.
Most recently in Ireland.
Major, what do you know about Bolivia?
-In South America, Sir? -That's right.
Only what I've read.
Hm. Then you can't know very much.
This is as good a map of Bolivia as we have.
Most of it's blank, as you can see. Nothing's really known about it at all.
But there are rubber plantations all over Amazonia.
Very profitable.
There is now considerable argument between Bolivia and Brazil, as to what constitutes their border.
So fantastically high is the price of rubber, that war could arise.
Do you follow?
-I do, Sir. -Mm-hm.
Although, I'm not sure what this has to do with me.
Neither country will accept mapping done by the other, so they've requested us to act as referee.
Mm. As you've completed your mapping here with distinction, you came under our consideration.
-I see. -Mm-hm.
-Sirs, may I speak candidly? -Please.
My survey work was long ago.
And to be quite honest, I was rather hoping for a position -where I might see a fair bit of action. -Major.
This is far more than just survey work.
This is exploration in the jungle.
The environment's brutally difficult.
Terrible disease.
Murderous savages. The journey may well mean your life.
At the very least, you will be gone for several years.
such an undertaking could earn you soldierly decoration.
And...
even reclaim your family name.
Did you?
Yes.
I did not.
Terrible thing...
A man's love of drink and gaming.
But as I say, success in this venture could change your lot.
Considerably.
-Like that. -Does it look big, like a big brain?
It looks round.
Jack, will you go and play?
I want to talk to your father for a minute.
He'll not know you when you return.
I have something to tell you.
I believe I'm going to have another child.
I know I'm having another child.
Don't be sad.
I'm an independent woman.
Cheeky... Darling...
I know this is a sacrifice for all of us.
But it will be worth it.
Henry Costin.
I applied to your advert in the Times.
I'm your aide-de-camp.
-Mr. Costin? -Reporting for duty, Sir.
We've been at sea a week. Why are you just presenting yourself now?
I wanted to make sure you were up to the task, Sir.
-Are you drunk, Mr. Costin? -No.
Well...
Well...
I've got a... letter of commendation.
You'll see I'm both skilled at rifle and pistols.
A medal for bravery.
That's very impressive.
I see, so nothing to shed.
I take it you do then.
Mr. Costin, I would like to be clear.
My reputation as a man rests entirely on our success.
I think you shall find me capable of every sacrifice.
Therefore, I must insist...
Oh! Right you are, Sir.
-We'll need all the fortitude you've got. -Understood.
We have new orders. To map the Verde River.
Find its source.
It forms a critical part of the border between Bolivia and Brazil.
Our survey route is to begin at a place called Fazenda Jacobina, which does not appear to be on this map.
I know Fazenda Jacobina.
It's an old rubber town. It's meant to be quite enchanting.
Really? You may not be completely useless after all.
Time is of the essence now.
War is at stake.
So you and I and a couple of mules are going to stop a war?
Well you and I... are going to have to depend on each other.
Neither of us will survive this alone.
Right you are.
What's that you're reading?
A poem, from my wife, by Kipling.
It's called The Explorer.
Apt.
Would you like to hear it?
Be my guest.

â€œThere's no sense in going further, it's the edge of cultivation, so they said, and I believed it, broke my land and sowed my crop, built my barns and strung my fences, Till a voice, as bad as Conscience, rang interminable changes, on one everlasting Whisper day and night repeated, so...
Something hidden.
Go and find it.
Go and look behind the Ranges, Something lost behind the Ranges.
Lost and waiting for you.
Go!
Sixteen minutes south of the equator.
Twenty-nine.
Six...
Sixteen.
Rather deadly looking snake here.
We might be a little bit too English for this jungle.
Is that you?
-Yes. -Welcome to Fazenda Jacobina.
Lance Corporal Manley, Sir, liaison to the Governor General-- No need to stand on ceremony. A simple handshake will suffice.
This is Mr. Costin.
I hate to be the bearer of bad news...
but I have received a telegram from the border commission.
They strongly advise you to... abort the mission.
It's become far too dangerous, Sir.
-They've already fighting-- -Where are the government offices?
Sir...
Government, Sir?
I'm afraid you've left government behind a longtime ago.
Well, in that case, you'd better send them a telegram...
informing them that we will not stand down and we shall proceed as planned.
How quickly can you find us an Indian guide?
Well, I...
I had an Indian guide Sir, but...
But what happened to him?
Not quite, Sir.
It's out of my hands now.
You need to speak to Baron De Gondoriz. He runs the rubber company here.
Good evening, Baron. Thank you for seeing us.
We are from the British Army.
We're to be venturing up the Rio Verde, and find ourselves in need of some of your men.
In exchange, I promise very favorable treatment from my country.
You goin' up river, are ya?
Yes.
We're surveying.
Well...
Ain't nobody comes back from up there.
This slave good enough for you?
Yes.
What will you take for him? And any four men of his choosing?
It offends you to negotiate with me.
You come here to make maps.
Why is that?
So that there may be peace?
What is peace?
Peace means my business would flourish.
I would flourish.
Because you will make sure that nothing will change.
It came directly here while you were surveying.
Can you show me how far the river goes?
They're as dependable as any that can be found here, Mr. Costin.
We're the only ones who will pay them.
We'll do twelve hours a day... no less.
but, but I can't catch them.
The river is deep here. There is plenty of fish.
It's a desert.
A green desert.
All right, pull it in.
Try again further up.
Come to load rubber, no doubt.
There's someone aboard.
Hey!
Costin! Piranhas!
Get out of the water!
It's nothing.
Are we close?
Even the Indian's gone mad now.
He was talking to me about gold cities today.
Those Indians seemed a bit mad to begin with.
I'd like you to read this to me if you can.
I'm afraid it would be quite unbearable for me to read it myself.
Right you are, Sir.
Your wife has moved the family to Devon.
She's given birth to a boy named Brian.
Your oldest boy, Jack, is excelling in all ways, she says.
What kind of fool am I, to leave my family for this place?
What did you hope to achieve out here?
I don't know.
Food gone.
One piece.
Give me that!
We are not savages.
And for what'?
A map?
Even if we get there, we're not making it back without any food.
Have you ever thought about that?
We're here starving to death.
Let's have at him.
Ah! My ear! My ear!
We made it!
Major, we've lost the Indian.
He got us here.
-Am I dreaming this? -No... I see it too.
Please.
Thank God.
Couldn't have done that better myself, Sir.
in the ground.
Look it's all over.
Christ. He was right.
The Indian was right.
You said no one had been here before.
I think you meant no white man Mr. Costin. I think you meant no white man.
There must've been dwellings here.
The exit from hell is always difficult, Mr. Costin.
But we will get back.
The world will know what we've found here.
Thank you. Thank you.
Thank you, Sir.
This must be Brian.
Are you my father?
I am, indeed, son.
Come, give me a hug.
Let's go home.
Thank you all.
Percy, come. Meet our host, Mr. James Murray.
He's very anxious to meet you.
A person of considerable resources.
He certainly has a beautiful home.
Major Fawcett, I see you down there.
Thank, Mr. Murray.
Listen to them, will you?
I'm just honored to be here, Sir.
I read your article in The Times this morning...
about the... slave trade in the Americas. It's uh...
You're an enlightened man.
The native does deserve our sympathy.
I think we have only just scratched the surface of Amazonia.
I was, um...
Well, I'm a biologist, but I'm also somewhat of an explorer.
I was second in command under Shackleton in the Antarctica.
I don't think there's anyone here who's not well aware of your accomplishments, Mr. Murray.
Here, here.
Well, it's been my lifelong ambition to...
go to the Amazon, you know?
Well, I must say, I hope that the RGS continues its pursuits, but I...
I have come to believe that mapmaking should be a secondary interest.
Really?
I witnessed several archaeological discoveries, that I believe may have enormous significance.
My friend, a word in your ear, please.
Um, your, your exploits have opened every door for you.
But I would suggest keeping such findings to yourself.
Mm-hmm.
I mean, no one here would dispute that you believed what you saw, but...
such a trip is very hard on the mind...
very hard, indeed.
Mr. Keltie.
I think you should find my mind perfectly fit.
And still open, thank heavens.
I would like to introduce one of our brothers...
whose achievements are now known to you... and not inconsiderable.
Major Percy Fawcett.
Thank you, Sir.
By rights, I should be with my husband.
It's, it's men only I'm afraid, madam.
it is now my firm belief...
that Amazonia, is far more than the green desert which many of us had supposed.
I am proposing that Amazonia...
contain a hidden civilization...
I am Mr. William Barkley of Bedford, and I have been to South America.
Please, Mr. Barkley, I'm sure we'd all be thrilled to hear about your holiday.
But we are currently discussing exploration.
Are you insisting on mythical kingdoms of gold?
lured the conquistadors to their destruction.
Sir, it was the conquistadors and we, who have been destroying Amazonia.
I have seen, with my own eyes, evidence of their civilization.
And I assure you, Sir, it is real.
Perhaps it is too difficult for some of you to admit.
We, who have been steeped in the bigotry of the church for so long, cannot give much credence to an older civilization.
Particularly one created by a race the white man has so brutally condemned to slavery and death.
Are, are you insisting that these savages, they're our equals?
I do not know, Mr. Barkley, but I intend to find out.
If we may find a city...
where one was considered impossible to exist...
It may well write a whole new chapter in human history.
Yes! Yes!
I have archaeological finds.
Antiquities as sophisticated as any in Asia or Europe...
in the middle of the jungle!
Pots and pans!
Pans! Pots and pans!
After my return from the jungle, I have examined a single document, dating from the conquistadors, Mr. Barkley!
It states explicitly the discovery of a lost city.
Uncovered in Trinity College, Dublin, this week by my lovely wife.
Written by a Spanish soldier in 1753, and I quote...
We came upon the ruins of an ancient city bedecked with gold.
Roads...
Temples...
Ancient symbols...
The ultimate piece of the human puzzle!
It is there and we must find it!
Mr. Fawcett!
Mr. Fawcett, I say we return!
What I say, Mr. Murray...
is I accept that challenge!
I see you seated there.
Mr. Fawcett.
That jungle is hell, but... one kind of likes it.
We shall return!
With this journey, we may be able to tear down their narrow minded convictions.
I do believe I am quite ready to accompany on your next journey.
What do you mean?
The children will be back in school by then.
And I have learned to read the stars...
and navigate.
And I've become very well versed in the history of the region.
After all, it is I who found the document.
But that would be impossible.
It's not a place at all for a woman.
Not a place for a woman?!
We believe firmly in the equality between us.
In equality, yes, but in mind, not in body.
Ah.
The rigor of such a trip would be beyond your imagination.
I believe it is generally acknowledged that the pain a woman experiences during childbirth far exceeds anything a man must endure.
-This is not about childbirth. -Oh, what would you know of childbirth?
Have you witnessed two minutes of it, let alone endured it?
The jungle...
is about years of practice...
training, the art of soldiering.
I have that.
It is about maggots in your skin. It is about deadly snakes and disease that make you vomit blood.
You could not bear it.
And I could not bear that either.
Somehow I managed to bear the dangers you faced the years you were gone.
This way, at least, we me might be together for some of our lives!
You are my wife!
I need you here.
And in this fantasy of yours, what happens to the children?
Please, try to be reasonable.
You will throw reasonable in my face.
Was it reasonable to stay here and struggle to provide for the children while you wandered the jungle?
Now you have given no thought, not one thought, to my aspirations as a woman.
Have you thought about that?
Men and women have performed their roles since the beginning of time!
and I am disgraced by your ignorant posture!
Mother!
It's all right, darling.
It's all right, Jack. Go.
You should put some grease on that.
Will do.
Where's Mr. Murray?
He's bringing up the rear, chief.
Mr. Murray!
How are you managing?
I am managing well, thank you.
My pack is just a little heavy it seems.
Perhaps I shall...
rid myself of the unnecessary accoutrements, yes?
I wouldn't do that if I were you.
However...
an awful lot of this...
scientific equipment seems to be slowing us down.
When we reach the river then.
But you must keep one spare set of clothing.
And, of course, your mattress.
What a site that would be.
Let's keep going.
That bugger wishes he was back on the South Pole.
He'll pull his weight soon enough. Don't worry.
You've got two from your wife and son, Major.
There's been a major discovery in Peru.
Oh, and an American...
Hiram Bingham, he's found the lost city in the Andes, Machu Picchu.
He's too far north.
We've lost the other boat.
Savages!
-Arm yourselves! -No! Hold your fire.
Everyone out of the boat.
Mr. Manley!
Get your concertina.
-My concertina, Sir? -Yes, do it now!
Play Soldiers of the Queen!
Mr. Costin, come and sing with me.
Are you ready?
If the red man attacks.
You rally to me at all costs.
Oh, good God...
We are safe.
The chief has invited us to be his guest.
I know. I know.
The chief explained it's a dead member of their tribe.
His spirit will enter them if they eat it.
We must attempt to engage.
They may have critical information about our destination.
I'm... I refuse this madness.
I refuse it.
He's heard rumors of a city, but he's not sure.
He said further up the river he thinks there will be people who can help us.
All right, then.
That is remarkable.
It's mathematical in its precision.
Imagine what Z must be like.
We leave at sunrise.
James?!
James?!
Hello, old sport.
I appear to have gotten myself lost.
cannibalized by those... savages.
You'll be looked after. Come.
I think I have a bit of a fever coming on.
Manley, help me clean all of this up.
It was a gift from my wife and children for all of us to share.
I know. I was just very...
hungry.
I'm a little bit tired. If you don't mind I'm going to rest for a... while longer.
My own children, at their tender ages, could be counted on more than you.
And I could be home... with them.
And yet, I am here with you...
to attempt great things.
Have you water please?
You'll get water when we get to the raft.
Mr. Manley, help me get him on his feet.
Stay where you are, Mr. Murray.
It's essential we keep the balance.
Murray!
Stay down, God damn you!
Swim to shore!
We're losing supplies! God damn you!
Mr. Manley, help me!
Chief! We've lost a third of our rations.
And this after you stole our food!
I suppose I should have starved myself.
That would have been the honorable course of action, wouldn't it?
I just want to be dead.
young upstart and his vulgar quest for glory...
Like a Judas...
he has delivered me...
into this...
jungle.
Well, we're two weeks behind...
according to the sextant and the charts.
Chief.
I noticed.
the hem of your garment...
As I...
am not worthy of yours.
No... No...
Yes? What is it'?
There are mining encampments south of us on the river.
In the morning, you'll be on your way to them.
with what supplies I can spare and an Indian to guide you.
I have a family at home.
I cannot allow you to jeopardize the welfare of the entire crew.
You don't give a wit about me...
or about any of the party.
You don't even care about going home.
You only care...
about your lost...
city.
I'm going to see if there's a path through!
I saw it!
We're getting close!
Keep going!
And this is how he repays us.
Rations ruined! Murray's covered them in oil!
Look at it!
There is no turning back.
We are right here!
We've nothing to show for our efforts.
With what we have on our backs, we'll last a week at most!
It's over, Percy!
Mr. James Murray was forced to separate from our expedition, to seek medical attention.
and he has most likely perished.
The rest of the group shall arrive back in England...
as soon as is possible.
It looks like a war with France.
Better all get home or we'll miss our chance to fight.
Please send that immediately.
Yes, Sir.
Beautiful child.
-I'll fetch the boys. -No.
Let them finish.
When they're done, send them in.
It should be I who tells them what has happened.
You're real.
Thank you for coming at such short notice.
Please, will you step this way?
Congratulations on your knighthood.
Ah, thank you. I think that you know everybody here.
Mr. James Murray arrived in London just this morning.
Congratulations on your safe return.
It's a remarkable effort.
No. It is not.
He was given money and food.
It was an unfortunate but necessary maneuver in order to save lives.
We spent all our time...
playing around in the mud with the savages.
And I never saw any evidence of a lost city.
You were the reason we did not reach our destination, Mr. Murray.
You poured paraffin on all our supplies.
And as for his lackeys... they are swine and not to be trusted.
You should've been beaten in the jungle like the dog that you are.
Our nation is now at war.
It ill becomes us to indulge personal conflicts.
I earnestly beseech you to come to an understanding.
Very well.
I most generously offer that...
If you are willing to apologize to me here in front of this entire society...
I will consider withdrawing my claims against the RGS and yourself...
with certain conditions, of course.
Well, Major.
Will you apologize?
For the general good...
I am prepared to reconcile.
I will, of course, need to hear Mr. Murray's conditions.
On the day that I agreed to join you on your mission...
and allowed your star to enter my sphere, your wife was present to witness your ascent.
My only condition is that she again be present to witness your acknowledgment, of the wrongs...
that you have done to me.
Sir.
The last time I saw you, I was putting you on the only remaining horse...
giving you far more than your share of our food.
The men begged me to leave you where you lay...
but I could not do that.
And as a consequence, I saved your life.
You saved my life?
I demand an apology right now.
You will apologize to me.
I will apologize...
Thank you.
to my men.
I'm sorry I ever considered Mr. Murray worthy of your company.
And as I ever mistook a man's rank for his mettle.
But I shall not make that mistake again.
What your purpose is in this ambush, I cannot say.
I hereby resign from this institution...
and I shall proceed on my own.
No, p-please, Major! Please!
This is outrageous! Please, you must reconsider!
Magnus!
I shall teach him.
What's wrong?
You've received a letter.
All former officers not currently posted, must send their names to the war office.
Let us hope it is a brief conflict.
Talk to the boys.
Don't be concerned, my love.
I've spent a whole life training for this.
Father...
Jack.
Brian.
I'll do it.
Father, you will not have to leave again, will you?
If the reports are true, I'm afraid I must.
Father, you've only just returned.
It's... it's hardly fair.
I'm obligated to serve.
What of your obligation to mother?
And to us?
Your family.
The... the family that you've chosen to abandon for so many years.
How dare you talk to me like that.
How dare... How dare you, father you...
You do not think of us.
or any other path to glory that you can find.
Jack, stop it! That's enough!
Mother, I will not stop. You have returned a failure.
-It's contemptible-- -Enough!
Everything your father has done, since the day you came into this world, has been to better your life.
you will come regret the things you just said to him.
It appears our old friend Mr. James Murray is not so powerful after all.
Why do you say that?
The bastard's gone off on an Artic expedition with Canadians and... mutinied.
Take a look.
Someone should warn the Eskimos that Mr. Murray is on the prowl.
Times up, let's make the Major do it. Come on!
There will be in battle soon, madam.
Any spiritual aid would be greatly appreciated.
You are the explorer?
I was.
I was with these fine men...
who have transferred here so we could all be together.
Give me your hand.
Is it... a forest?
You dream to be in a forest.
I wish to find a lost city.
see yourself there now?
Try to picture it in your mind.
I can see it.
is far greater...
than you ever imagined.
It is your destiny.
Our whole world has set itself afire...
We must look elsewhere to quench the blaze.
Good morning, gentlemen.
When I was younger...
I ventured all for king and country...
for place and rank.
I believed that to be the makings of a man.
But my travels have taught me...
such ambitions...
are mere phantoms.
we fight for our loves ones, as we should.
But they are not here.
So instead let us fight for each other.
Good luck.
And may God be with all of you.
Alright men! Into positions!
Come on! Push forward!
Gas!
Gas!
Gas!
Manley! Gas! Manley!
We are here.
The children are here.
Come.
That is Joan.
Let him feel your face. Come along.
See?
Where's Jack'?
Father, I'm here.
I thought I had died.
You were exposed to chlorine gas.
Your eyes were affected, but they are very confident that your sight shall return.
The rest of the men?
-Costin? -Mr. Costin was unharmed.
but it was the only one that did not retreat.
Thanks to you bravery, they are raising your rank to Lieutenant Colonel.
Lieutenant Colonel?
After all that he has done?
Jack.
about Amazonia.
I'm afraid you may never be able to return to your jungle.
You cannot think of these things right now.
I'm going to take the children for some air.
Father.
Jack.
Our readers have been asking where you've been since the war.
You may tell your readers I've recovered from my wounds and have been adapting to home life.
Your pursuits in South America have led to a tremendous interest in exploration in the Unites States.
There have been many new voyages planned.
Have there?
Yes, Dr. Hamilton Rice leaves for Brazil soon with radio and airplanes.
He's taking a large and very well-armed party.
Well, let us hope that Dr. Rice, with all his arms, does not destroy what he wishes to discover.
How did you find us here?
Well, your son, Colonel.
He wrote us a letter.
Thank you, father.
Practice makes perfect, you know?
I have something for you.
This was given to me... by a Guarayo Indian chief.
A great man.
It's yours now.
Thank you.
It must've been a glorious day.
You still believe in Z, do you not?
That we underestimated the Indian?
That is why we should go back.
You and I, together. We could find the city once and for all.
Jack...
I'm an old bastard now.
Father, you and I, we both know it. You easily outmatch my strengths.
And now you can see as clear as day again.
There is nothing stopping us.
Father.
The Americans will venture there with their guns.
And then we must pray that they do not destroy the Indian.
I want nothing more than to go with you, Father.
It's everything you've always wanted.
We would have to consult a higher authority.
But you've said so yourself with everything that's happened in Europe, it's not possible to choose a safe passage through life.
So many men near my own age did not return from the war.
And who is to say it will not happen again?
It could, mother.
It could happen again.
By all accounts, I should be furious because you've just...
You've just used my very own words against me.
And how can I refute them? They are my own.
All right, Joan, don't slap him.
Thank you. Off! Go on!
She hit me on the face.
Brian! I'm in the middle of a conversation!
Go and help you sister get some wood, please, from the log pile now.
Now!
Fight your own battles!
Mother, please...
There is little doubt that I would worry night and day...
about my boys in the jungle.
But we have never let fear determine our future.
That's all.
Mother, thank you.
Thank you, thank you, thank you!
-Father, this-- -Jack, Jack, Jack.
-We are not there yet. -I know.
We'll have to raise a great deal of money.
Go on. Let me talk to your mother.
Well, of course, I shall begin right away.

his vim and vigor...
I guarantee it would tear down your resistance in an instant.
Nope. Thank you, Nigel.
Chief, please don't misunderstand me. I'm...
this, I believe...
this search for Z...

You've come to doubt its existence?

I wish you success, my dear friend.
Top heavy missions get nowhere.

surviving by our wits.

I'm glad to see our nation is not to be left behind.

No, but I am proud to say that we did finally manage to meet them halfway.

Oh...

Yes.

The Society's highest honor...
the Founder's Gold Medal.
and then we meet again in Brazil.
-and Mr. Costin has a copy in safekeeping. -Yes, you've told me a thousand times.

You're a man now... responsible for you mother and sister's care.

All right?

and a new history!

and if we're lucky to see an opera.

Yes.

The rest of our party is returning home.

covered with painted pictures of men and horses.

and he reminds me, yet again, that we are all made of the same clay...

Stay calm.
